DOC.HEAD: Medical Facility Treats All
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is a pool report by Kathy Lewis of The Houston Post, Bill Clayton of the Houston Chronicle, Kevin Merida of The Dallas Morning News and Dick Thompson of Time Magazine.

The medical facilities set up in the converted classrooms of Balboa High School have been treating civilians as well as soldiers. They have tended everything from a 2-year-old girl with an amputated foot to a 73-year-old woman looking for insulin. They have patched up a large number of gunshot and shrapnel wounds and delivered one baby which was said to be healthy. However, Col. Michael McConnell _ who is the Southern Command's command surgeon _ said Wednesday's military injuries were ``significant'' in terms of seriousness, but he said they had been able to stabilize everyone. ``I'd be surprised if any of them died,'' he said. One of the Panamanian civilians, a tiny, gray haired woman wearing sandals cried that her home had been destroyed by the fighting. ``I don't have a thing,'' she said, ``just what I have on.'' Still the woman, who declined to give her name fearing retaliation, did not condemn the American action, said ``God bless America. The America fed my father. The America gave me everything. God bless America.'' Pfc. Doc Jurkiewicz, a 22-year-old who is from Dallas, Texas, was being treated for shrapnel in the left leg. He said he was injured as they were clearing buildings near the comandancia. The area already was on fire and apparently a gas tank blew. Though he was hurt last night, he stayed on and did not come in for treatment until Thursday morning. He said there were ``a lot of people'' still fighting. Jurkiewicz was the only soldier who was being treated during a tour by reporters Thursday morning. One or two of the military injuries had been very serious he said, ``The flack jackets saved many.'' Across the hall from where the soldier was being treated, several Panamanians were receiving medical attention. Some appeared to have serious injuries. Susana Rivero, an older woman, who got bumped into barbed wire was being treated for a cut on her left foot. She said her home in Chorrillo, a poor neighborhood near the PDF's headquarters was lost. ``Everything was bombed,'' she said. However, she said she was glad the Americans came and wants deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega killed. She spoke of him as still in office even though she had heard on the radio that President Guillermo Endara had been sworn in. ``He has destroyed everything,'' she said of Noriega. ``He did a lot of harm.'' She said he ought to be ``caught and killed.'' Asked if she were glad the Americans came even though she lost her home, she said, she was ``satisfied and calm'' and that the Americans had never done any harm.
